instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message:
"Small" water spill on the keyboard. Keyboard flex was destroyed. There was a small spot (picture attached) around <CAPACITOR>C7051</CAPACITOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR>. Cleaned around the two components. Replaced the flex cable and the machine boots, charges, and does boot into the OS.  Keyboard and touchpad work. 

When you first start the computer the CPU fan goes on and off about 10-15 times. If the battery is disconnected I have the fan issue but the computer runs normally. 

If the battery is connected it charges, has the same fan issue, but after login the computer shuts off after a minute or so. 

Other than just replacing the two components is there a way to test which one is the culprit? I currently do not have a donor board for this model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message:
Post exact voltage at F7000, w/ and w/o battery connected?
Also check the resistance over <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/30.

threads.message: Also... I tried a replacement keyboard/palm assembly and a new CPU fan. It does the same thing. I also located a donor board in my stack.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message: You should replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR>; check its traces and solders.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message: Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR>. The fan does not spin loudly every time.  Only the first time on a fresh boot. It stays on while charging now. The fan does not seem to run at all now. If I run apple diagnostic it does the loud fan spin and comes back there may be an issue with the fan Error PPF003.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message: I have swapped the fan with another but the same results. I guess I could order a new fan but I don't believe that will make a difference.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message:
Resistance
<RESISTOR>R4800</RESISTOR> - 36
<RESISTOR>R4805</RESISTOR> - 46
<RESISTOR>R4810</RESISTOR> - 100

On my donor board, I am getting....
<RESISTOR>R4800</RESISTOR> - 46
<RESISTOR>R4805</RESISTOR> - 46
<RESISTOR>R4810</RESISTOR> - 100

Would the <RESISTOR>R4800</RESISTOR> difference matter?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message: Possibly bad fan circuit, placed on the keyboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message: Moving the board to another case reproduces the same issue. SMC issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message:
May have crap under keyboard connector.
You've said was affected by liquid...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message: That's one connector that I do not want to remove unless I absolutely have to. Although the connector looks fine, there must be a damaged pad underneath, like you said. What would my options be to run a wire? Pins 2 and 3 of the connector are <SIGNAL>FAN_LT_PWM</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>FAN_LT_TACH</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message:
That only helps if no leakage between pins, caused by possibly crap underneath.
Is a chance, try and see...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message:
Logicboard Keyboard Connector.... 
No pins from the connector are shorted with the ones next to them. I check both sides of the connector for continuity. 
PIN 2 of the connector <SIGNAL>FAN_LT_PWM</SIGNAL> has continuity to <TRANSISTOR>Q4800</TRANSISTOR> pin 3
PIN 3 of the connector <SIGNAL>FAN_LT_TACH</SIGNAL> has continuity to <RESISTOR>R4800</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R4805</RESISTOR>

I have tried the logicboard in a known good palm rest/keyboard and new cable. I am waiting for a new keyboard connector to come in. Is the anything else that it could be other than the connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. After liquid cpu fan on then off
threads.message: You can try the SMC from donor board...
